channel.title: NPR Morning Edition
channel.description: Morning Edition takes listeners around the country and the world with multi-faceted stories and commentaries every weekday. Hosts Steve Inskeep, Leila Fadel, Michel Martin and A Mart√≠nez bring you the latest breaking news and features to prepare you for the day.

item.title: These students protested the Gaza war. Trump's deportation threat didn't silence them
item.description: NPR spoke with two international students about their decision to continue speaking out despite the government's aggressive effort to deport pro-Palestinian activists.

item.title: Real estate agent commissions too high? Flat-fee brokers offer an alternative
item.description: Agents have typically taken a commission on the sale of a home that totals 5% to 6% of the price. But new rules have created an opening for brokers who charge much less.

item.title: Republicans divided over Trump's massive tax bill
item.description: NPR's Steve Inskeep speaks with Rep. Mike Lawler, of New York State, about Republican divisions that threaten to derail the ongoing budget negotiations.

item.title: Trump's 'big, beautiful bill' faces continued resistance
item.description: The massive tax and immigration bill at the heart of President Trump's second term plans faces continued resistance from both moderates and hardliners.

item.title: Morning news brief
item.description: Trump's "big, beautiful bill" faces continued resistance, South Africa's president heads to the White House, DOGE tries to embed beyond the executive branch.

item.title: How two women-owned businesses are navigating Trump's tariffs
item.description: NPR's Michel Martin asks the heads of two women-owned businesses how they are navigating the swing in tariff levels on China.

item.title: Tennessee resumes executions after a three-year pause
item.description: After a three-year pause because of problems with execution drugs, Tennessee is resuming the practice saying it now has a safe way to administer a lethal injection.

item.title: Is federal help for homeless students at risk?
item.description: There's a federal law that helps homeless students get an education. It's administered by the U.S. Education Department, and schools worry there's no plan for the program if the department closes.

item.title: What's next for the United States Institute of Peace
item.description: A federal judge blocked the Trump administration's takeover of the United States Institute of Peace. NPR's Leila Fadel speaks with lawyer George Foote about the future of the institute.

item.title: Secretary of State Marco Rubio faces another grilling on the Hill
item.description: Secretary of State Marco Rubio faces another grilling on Capitol Hill, a day after his testy exchanges with his former colleagues on the Senate Foreign Relations Committee.
